bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to [L.O.?] Howard, February 12, 1942

div1.p: Hench thanks Howard for allowing him to visit and inquires about the location of the Howard-Reed letters, which Hench has been unable to find.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to [L.O.?] Howard, February 12, 1942
div1.p:
May I express my sincere appreciation for having the opportunity
of visiting you on my recent trip to Washington. At your suggestion I got
in touch with Miss Mabel Coleord at the Department of Agriculture but she
said that they had no letters of your or Reed's in their library of the
Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine. She put me in touch with Dr.
S. A. Rohwer and a Mrs. Miller who referred me to the Archives Building
where Mr. Schellenburg (or Shellenber) showed me what they had there.
Apparently some of the letter files of the Department of Agriculture have
been transferred to the Archives Building. They only had five letters of
Dr. Reed to you, about seven of Dr. Carroll to you, and none from Dr. Lazear
to you. There were only three or four carbon copies of your letters to
Reed and I don't believe any of Reed's letters to you were from Cuba.
Do you have any idea where these might be? I would appreciate it greatly
if you or your daughter could give me some further clue.

You were kind enough to say that you would send me a copy of
“A History of Applied Entomology”. If you have been unable to obtain a
copy I would be indeed sorry but I would like to know it as I will try
to look for it somewhere else.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
